paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper reports a novel TTR mutation D39Y associated with hereditary transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, detailing its biochemical characterization, penetrance data, and individual case information.

patients.demographics: 75-year-old male proband, 46-year-old female daughter, 43-year-old female daughter
patients.phenotype: Cardiac amyloidosis symptoms in the proband; asymptomatic in daughters

individual_records.phenotype_details: Dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity edema
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The proband presented worsening dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity edema over 1 year.
The proband’s eldest daughter was identified as carrying this heterozygous variant of TTR gene c.175G>T.
The proband and his two asymptomatic daughters were sequenced and analyzed.

functional_data.summary: The D39Y mutation exhibits compromised thermodynamic and kinetic stability compared to wild-type TTR.
assays: Kinetic stability measured by tetramer dissociation

variants.segregation_data: The D39Y variant segregates with disease in the proband and his affected family members.
variants.additional_notes: The study suggests that the decrease in functional tetrameric TTR concentration may serve as an indicator for disease age of onset in D39Y gene carriers.
key_quotes: Notably, the tetramer concentrations gradually increased from symptomatic D39Y gene carrier father, to asymptomatic D39Y gene carrier daughter, and further to wild type daughter.
The proband showed a novel homozygous missense variant at base position 175 in exon 2 of the TTR gene (c.175G>T), resulting in an aspartic acid change to tyrosine (p.D39Y).

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
